reviewText:
Tactical Massive Fun!

Great and deep game, fun, full of customization and well well done.

In Satellite Reign you will be put in control of four agents, unlockable by time and each one with different abilities.

The cyberpunk environment is wonderfully created and a pleasure for your eyes! Strategy will also be fundamental in this game as you will be given total freedom to pass your level as you prefer, following your own personal strategy, which is the greatest thing of this game.

The graphic looks really cool as previously said and it runs very smooth. The movements are smooth, everything runs perfectly. Great game by the team that made Syndicate Wars!

Videogame News, Indie Score: 8.8 | SUPER RECOMMENDED

reviewText:
Hello guys,

my first review here on Steam, so go easy on me. It will be a short review.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

First: 8/10

This game is all in all pretty great. I was first considering not to buy it at all - I didn't know what I will get from buying this.
It's a game like the older game 'Commander' (was it called like that?), were you  command your soldiers behind enemy lines in an isometric view. Every soldier for themselves with special features and tricks. Not like Company of Heroes!
But this game happens in the future, with loads and lots of loadouts and gear and other crazy stuff. There's almost no voicing story but some short texts - reading is the most thing you'll need to do to get behind the story.
The gameplay is pretty great - there is no pausebutton were you can give your soldiers a command. But your supportunit can slow down time to help you with that. But don't get me wrong - you can always press escape and pause into game menu, but you can't give any commands here! It makes this game all in all a bit more challenging - talking about challenge: the game is not easy. But it is fair. Shooting your way through will not be possible, you really need to be strategic and consinder different tactics.
It is an open world game - so you can do sidequest after sidequest before going to other districts and do your job there.

Conclusion:

Buy it, if you liked XCOM. Buy it, if you like strategy games with being tactical. Buy it, if you need something to fill the gab until XCOM 2. Buy it if you love a future setting.

8/10!

reviewText:
Comming as older gamer who has played the Syndicate titles when they were first released, I was looking forward to this title,  After playing the tutorial part I found it a bit confusing and overwhemed I guess, as I have gotton used to a bit more structure in my titles.

But after a few hours of play I have gotton to grips how the game operates, and the punishment for losing a clone is'nt very servere, I would of liked a better introdution to what was Main MIssions and what were side missions at least for a few more missions. I am pleased the developers whave introduced the slow mo stims for players at the start as although I am not using this I can see why people want a real time tactical pause.

I can understand if players are confused and frustrated at the start of the game, but please stick at it as its a wonderful game, but It could just do with a bit more user friendly at the start for younger gamers who have'nt played this type of genre before, but I suppose the game was pitched at old gits like me. Hopefully this will sell decent, but I think it was a bad time to release it out of early access. With Metal Gear Solid and Mad Max a similiar time, PC gamers need this style of games, but hopefully this will attract a younger crowd.

reviewText:
I missed Syndicate. I missed a squad of cyborg killers wreaking havoc in a city that looked like a cross between a scrap yard and an adroid roller disco - until now! Thank you 5 Lives. I hope my cash hurled at railgun velocity is the thanks you are after.  Here's some more...

Nice squad mechanic - I'm a fan of the specialists.  I did get caught with my kevlar cyberkecks down a few times by sending the wrong agents to the wrong parts of a secure area (it's not Syndicate!), and wandering into security cameras (Not Syndicate!) but gradually turning the 4 sociopaths into a well oiled machine, while waiting to see if they get well oiled machine parts to match (like Syndicate!).

reviewText:
Remember Deus Ex? The gameplay in this is very similar, only instead of playing a first person cyberpunk, you control a team of FOUR cyberpunks, with different augmentations and abilities you can upgrade. Sneak past patrols, make silent takedowns, steal data from corporations and fight your way out when you get spotted. Like Deus Ex, each area has multiple entrances and paths to the objective. You must plan a route through patrols, hazards and one-way entry points, to infiltrate, and also exfiltrate with the loot and minimum casualties.

Instead of missions, you get a cool little sandbox metropolis, spotted with guarded compounds your team can infiltrate, and hiding spots for when they get out with the loot. There's an alert level system similar to cops in GTA, and a public/restricted area system similar to Hitman.

This game deserves more sales than it has, because it does a very rare thing: provide emergent gameplay with multiple solutions to every problem. For example, here's a list of ways you can get past a locked gate:
1) Hack the control terminal - requires hacking level, takes a few seconds, hacker may get spotted.
2) Blow the door up - loud, every patrol will come running, but the door will be gone.
3) Slip in when a patrol opens it - use cloaking, or just kill them all once you're inside.
4) Do side objectives - many missions will let you gain access by bribing or persuading" someone on the inside.
5) Mind-control a guard and make him open it - for bonus points

reviewText:
Made by an Australian developer, 5Live Studios, based in Brisbane, this game pays homage to Syndicate of the early 1990s but in a way that more resembles XCom Enemy Unkown insofar as:
- it's a very pretty game,
- there are significant streamlinings to the game systems
- the emphasis is on fun, rather than on punishing the player...

Some people think that XCOM casualised for the console market, but I disagree, and believe that it was an excellent example of how to make a game for people that no longer have the time to invest in games as they once did.

Satellite Reign is such a game that it respects the players' time, with a brief but very helpful tutorial system that orientates you to the game world and a number of streamlinings (fast travel) that make it so much easier to have a play for a little while in between feeding a baby (personal example) or cooking dinner...

The game looks fantastic, it plays brilliantly and is intelligent in design and very well-structured. A credit to the studio - you made a triple-A game on a shoestring budget. Thank you for your work, I hope you are all very well rewarded. Congratulations ! :)

reviewText:
Hello guys,

my first review here on Steam, so go easy on me. It will be a short review.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

First: 8/10

This game is all in all pretty great. I was first considering not to buy it at all - I didn't know what I will get from buying this.
It's a game like the older game 'Commander' (was it called like that?), were you  command your soldiers behind enemy lines in an isometric view. Every soldier for themselves with special features and tricks. Not like Company of Heroes!
But this game happens in the future, with loads and lots of loadouts and gear and other crazy stuff. There's almost no voicing story but some short texts - reading is the most thing you'll need to do to get behind the story.
The gameplay is pretty great - there is no pausebutton were you can give your soldiers a command. But your supportunit can slow down time to help you with that. But don't get me wrong - you can always press escape and pause into game menu, but you can't give any commands here! It makes this game all in all a bit more challenging - talking about challenge: the game is not easy. But it is fair. Shooting your way through will not be possible, you really need to be strategic and consinder different tactics.
It is an open world game - so you can do sidequest after sidequest before going to other districts and do your job there.

Conclusion:

Buy it, if you liked XCOM. Buy it, if you like strategy games with being tactical. Buy it, if you need something to fill the gab until XCOM 2. Buy it if you love a future setting.

8/10!

reviewText:
TL;DR: Visually one of the best designed game worlds i have seen in a while, and one with solid gameplay to boot. If you can forgive a few glitches and some occasional NPC stupidity it is well worth the price. See the “The Verdict” section for a short list of pro’s and cons.

Intro - What is the game about?Satellite Reign takes place in a cyberpunk world ruled by corporations rather than governments. Your objective is to to overthrow the Dracogenics company and overtake their resurrection network of satellites. This is mostly a background for the game though - during the game the story itself is thin so do not expect an opus magnum quality novel. A few spoken notes at the start of each district and some background text from hacked terminals is pretty much al the story that is availible.

You play the game as a squad of four characters, each with its own specialization and talents. You are free to upgrade your characters as you wish – a single play trough will most definitely not unlock all their skills – even half may be out of reach. Aside from that you customize their weapons, tools, armor and the like. These tools partially mimic other class abilities so you can create a pretty neat customized squad, perfect for your playing style.

The gameplay itself resolves around breaching ever-more-difficult compounds on the map, looting them for money and gear prototypes you can then use to support your own soldiers. Money can either be spend on new weapons or researching the gear you found so you can duplicate it. Aside from that it is only used for bribes to make objectives simpler or to bypass sections of the game.

Infiltration – Silent as a shadow or loud and clear?Infiltrating compounds can be done through both stealth and brute force, both of which have their advantages and disadvantages. Going silent allows you to bypass difficult fights entirely, but being caught can be quite lethal. Going loud could get you swarmed with enemies, but it will create a clear path with little surprises behind you.

Both paths are surprisingly well developed and complemented by the available gear and skills. Players focusing on stealth will develop skills that allow them to access high vents  and ziplines, which can bypass areas of the map. Loud players will not want to waste points on these skills and will instead take a different path using skills that increate damage. Regardless of your gametype there are always multiple paths to a single objective, which always creates a tactical consideration: Will I just blow up those turrets and then fortify myself for a fight, or so I take one of those two routes around them and risk being spotted and ganged up by half the base?

The verdict – Pro’s and Con’s
Pros
Open world gameplay:  The entire world is accessible from the start of the game and there is no loading screen whatsoever during gameplay, not even when switching zones in the city.
Outstanding visual quality: The world is exceptionally well designed. Visual quality is very high, and of such variety that you will have difficulty finding area’s that look alike.
Customization: The character customization can personalize a squad to your wishes, with sufficient options to make them feel “Unique”
Replay value: My stealth and loud games feel sufficiently different to warrant another playtrough. Even a third which mixes skills from both might be an option.
Well optimized: My current system is medium specced at best. The game runs flawlessly with a high framerate trough, and looks very appealing.
Playing around: Hijacking 5 citizens and setting them on a guard is never boring, nor is causing a fight between two corporations. Neither will luring a set of guards to a spot with gunfire before throwing a grenade get old. Plenty of tactics around that are fun just because they are possible.
Neutral
Game time: My first stealth game took about 40 hours to complete, though I did play around with the game world a lot rather than progressing. My second loud playtrough is going faster. All in all I suspect most players will find around 20-30 hours’ worth of time in a single play trough. Less if you are rushing, more if you are playing around.
Cons
The AI:  The AI in the game can be rather dumb at times. If you find a dead body you shouldn’t charge in on your own. If you are in a gunfight, you don’t pell-mell trough the gunfire to take cover near the enemy. If you chase an enemy at the heart of your base you don’t search a minute on your own and return to patrol afterwards without even raising the alarm.
Pathfinding: You will see NPC’s running into closed doors or standing in from of them without taking the 10 second detour around. You will see your men cut corners to shortly only for them to stagger into the terrain. You will see your own soldiers and enemies run into standing cars. It is not always a problem, but often enough to take note off.
Glitches: Hijacked civilians can run through closed doors if they sprint to them. Citizens entering vents can end up exiting in mid-air instead of the other end. Positioning between walls and objects can glitch you inside the building or wall. Again somewhat rare and you can always correct it yourself, but definitely an immersion breaker.
The open world: The world is well designed, but feels somewhat devoid of objectives at times. You travel trough it to reach compounds and wander around it for ATM's, terminals and scientists and the occasional quest objective. These are one-off's though. A few procedurally generated and repeatable side missions to assasinate a squad or breach an enemy compound might have been fun to keep wandering around more interesting.
All in all I can heartily recommend this game both at a discount and at its full price. Visually the game is excellent. Both the gameplay and level design is done well enough to support a variety of tactics and play styles – there is no “Only” or “Best” way to play the game. If you can forgive its quirks and glitches it will make up with the rest it has to offer.

reviewText:
Have been playing it for a little while. I bought it for two reasons: firstly because I was a fan of Syndicate back in the day, even though I sucked at it and probably still do; and secondly, because a friend of mine tried to get me into the Netrunner card game, which I would have liked to do if I had the cash to burn and the guarantee of regular matches in my MtG loving country.

But I digress. This seems pretty cool so far. The system for hijacking agents and cloning them is a bit confusing --- actually, no, it's very confusing, and the un-intuitive interface doesn't help. I'd recommend checking out some YouTube vids explaining it. Otherwise, everything else is easy enough to figure out with a bit of tinkering.

It's great fun. I tend to play it as a top-down stealth game, but I'm still rather early in - and I'll explain why momentarily - but on the whole, it's great fun circling compounds trying to find all the access points and planning which route you're going to take and such. It might get to the point later where I'll have to beef up and take a more combative approach to some missions, though.

The reason I'm not too far is because the game is fairly stable (on my Windows 10 PC) until I try to load a game. Then a crash is about 50/50 likely to occur. Maybe this has been fixed in the cloth dynamics patch. I'll have to check.

But on the whole, if you liked Syndicate, and could do with that kind of gameplay in an open world, be sure to check it out.

reviewText:
To claim this is the 'spiritual successor' of Syndicate is a dishonour and an outright lie, shame on 5 lives studios.

No drivable cars, no environmental destruction, no 'weird/crazy' weapons/gadgets like Syndicate, semi personalised characters, no world/corporate domonation... group feels like petty armed thugs running around the 'dead' streets killing and stealing with no purpose, not some organised, professional group fighting for or bringing down mega corps working from some secret base/HQ/whatever (I think my 'agents' live on the street, I mean you couldn't assume anything else as there is no home base).... it feels pointless and without meaning.

- AI both NPC and character AI is horrible and frustrating.
- Bugs, glitches and poor performance.... still today (2016)
- Weapons are boring and simple and seriously lack diversity... no strange and weird weapons like Syndicate or SW and weapon attachments are no subsitute for the weird and awesome weapons of the originals
- Augmentations are weak and boring in terms of diversity/types.
- No tactical pause, which is needed with terrible AI pathfinding and no combat mode/stance.
- Cities feel hollow and dead, things move around but its no living city.
- The environment is beautiful
- Cannot configure my agents as they have 'personality', clones/agent are meant to be a base/stock unit I can configure and build how I like but they are pre-defined archetypes I can only slightly modify them from whats forced... imo ruins the whoile idea
- Backers still haven't received the physical rewards.
- Game world looks beautiful, but then so does thief2014.... both are boring lackluster game.

Please smarktard devs, stop ruining classics by remaking shallow, boring junk... if you're not going to do it properly f'k off.

I want to love it but imo SR badly missed the mark.... this is in no way a spiritual successor to Syndicate.... its noting like it, its like some sh|tty company has ripped the idea of Syndicate and make some very pretty but seriously broken mess.

reviewText:
One of the best games I've played in a loooong time. I cannot emphasize how much I want a map editor or expansion or anything that gives me more of this game. I will pay. Please!

Actual review:
This game plays like a combination of Fallout Tactics and Wasteland 2. That is to say, the excellent TBS/ RTS combat from FO:T, combined with the skills-that-really-matter from WL2.
Infiltrating bases to steal blueprints for awesome weapons, hacking turrets to attack enemies, siphoning money from ATMs... This game is truly the best-realized cyberpunk setting I've ever seen in a video game.

Pros:
- Lots of ways to go about missions. A lot of games SAY they have this. Not many really do. This one does.
- Good variety of weapons and tools.
- Good progression that lets you set your goals: want a rocket launcher instead of a hacking upgrade? Break into this complex instead of that one.

I'm sure there are cons, but I'm writing this after a few months since I finished playing it, and nothing pops into my head. No glitches, no crashes, no horrible mechanics I hated. As such, I'll leave the 'cons' to others.

reviewText:
Satellite Reign is very much a successor to Syndicate and Syndicate Wars, and not just in a spiritual sense. The aesthetics, the music, the angles everything is very much Syndicate Wars 2.0, sadly this includes not only the good parts, but also some of the warts.

Once the action really gets going, it can frankly be impossible to react, not only because stuff can happen in the blink of an eye, but also because agents are often very unwilling to abandon actions they're already in the process of executing, and because if two things that can be interacted with overlap, the game sometimes insists that what you REALLY want to do is click that vent, not the enemy trying to gun you down. Agents also aren't terribly clever, they occasionally have navigation issues, and you'll NEVER want to use rocket launchers, because they rarely think to shoot OVER or AROUND obstructions immediately in front of them(and there's no indication of the rocket's trajectory or blast radius to you, the player, though there is for usable items such as grenades. Perhaps the rocket launcher and its siblings should have been usable items, not main weapons, if it's an issue with the interface?).

There are also a few weird bugs left over, largely related to extreme height differences. For instance, I had an escort mission where an escort, upon entering a vent would, rather than leaving its exit point, leave its exit point... but be severely displaced on the Y axis, resulting in me not being able to take him on the same path as my agents.

Overall, I enjoyed Satellite Reign, though it was definitely at its best when I could maintain stealth, because the combat... wasn't very fun. The weapon stats almost all looked basically the same, with few indicators of when something was more efficient than something else, and combat tended to be over pretty quickly in any case, because there was rarely any strategy that worked better than liberally spamming grenades(crazily overpowered if you maxed your Soldier's ability to carry and use them) and then focusing fire on the survivors(you rarely have any real reason to split up your guys except in the early game before they can all use the same navigation options thanks to augmentations, so focus fire is an option in 99% of all cases).

Triggering an alarm was also often not a huge deal, even without silencers it was often possible to just off the guards with no reinforcements coming, and at worst it was an extra wave or two. On the one hand I like that one mistake didn't send me zooming off to the quickload button like in some stealth-involving games, but on the other hand sometimes it felt just a tad TOO forgiving, too.

The AI also tended to have some weird decision-making at times, triggering random repercussions against civilians and even inter-factionally(as another group than the one owning a given compound would sometimes show up to investigate destroyed security cameras there).

The ending was also a major letdown. It was over just a bit too quickly, though thankfully it maintained a health level of challenge(getting cocky almost got me totally gibbed), and then the reward" at the end  was just hearing some British woman yelling swear words and insisting that "She" betrayed us! Oh no! And then everyone explodes. Considering that I could probably figure out who "She" was

reviewText:
I played all the way through the game, and while it has moments of enjoyment, it is more bad than good.

First off, the bad.
* The game plays fine for the first 15 to 16 hours, but after that mark, bugs begin appearing in mass, most of which effect gameplay in frustrating ways. Pausing respawning all enemies in the world, for example. Soldiers aiming in a completely different direction than their indended target. Soldiers refusing to move or shoot, and getting stuck in place or in terrain.
* The game has a poor progression system - that is, linear. There is no reason to use Plasma over Laser based weaponry, for example, when both are unlocked so close to one another. The game pauses during inactivity, which hinders the research function whenever you are waiting before infiltrating an enemy region.
* The story is next-to non-existent, as is the environmental interaction.
* There are traces of unfinished features all over the game, leaving a feeling of yearning for what could have been. Vehicles are present, but pose no threat and serve no purpose.
* The relay system should have been either removed or toned down drastically.
* While there are plenty of hotkeys, some of the more trivial tasks that one must always do in momments of fast-paced high-risk action seem to have been overlooked.
* Certain graphics settings have either no effect on the visuals or frame-rate, even when disabled.
* Lack of narrative progression after tutorial and before the final boss."
* Lack of enemy variety.
* Enemies do not use many tactics
date: and are keen to sit and shoot until killed.\n\nNow
recommended: the good.\n* Exceptionally long game. Each area takes roughly 10 hours to complete on a speed run.\n* Customizable difficulty. This makes the stealth-play far more important

reviewText:
This game is half done gameplay. The only good things relatively well done are the stealth, the graphics and the animations of the whole town, and the writing is ok but nothing great, and that's it.

The combats means controlling real time 4 characters with zero pauses and they have ZERO AI!!! Any RTS do much better since 20+ years, lol. There's covering, movements, weapons switching and targeting, if a character get shoot he doesn't fire back nor even go in cover, the controls are still rather bad, and there's a lot of abuse of enemies spawning. That's ridiculous.

The economy is also ridiculous with a system where you just wait time to get more money. For sure some missions allow get more money but that free money mechanism break all and pinpoint the inability to build a true gameplay.

Other than that everything else is at level of a casual game, hacking is a simple click and a short cooldown, rob a bank is a simple click, and so on.

Maybe there's some good gameplay there, but the frame rates I'm getting are horrible. The PC runs everything else fine, including Fallout 4, but I'm getting like 15-20 FPS on Satellite Reign. Unfortunately, looking at the Steam forums this seems to be a fairly commong thing. Sat Reign just doesn't seem to be optimized very well.

It's too bad too - the game play seemed interesting and I absolutely love the visual style. But due to exceptionally poor frame rates I'm going to have to refund this puppy.

reviewText:
Welcome to my blog for more reviews on more platforms and other things about gaming: http://silverthorns.kinja.com

Did not finish the game, so I am not in the position to write a review. Just state the reason I cannot finish it:

1. Your soildier has no AI at all. You have to manage their position, target and skills in the battle. You might even need to split them in different places and multitask. The developer assumes every player of the game is a professional Starcraft II player and refuse to let me pause and give command. Yes, the supporter has a skill to mimic that but you know that is not what I mean.

2. Stealth gameplay is also broken. Guards' patrol route is completely random. It is very ambiguous where their line of sight can reach and how light and cover affect their vision. Still due to the lack of pause, it is vert difficult to split your team and cooperate efficiently. This engine does not fit for stealth gameplay at all. It is like being forced to play a stealth game in an real time strategy game.

3. The game is filled with Ubisoft-style activity. Establishing stations all over the map as a fast travel spot; hack ATM all over the map to give your constant currency flow; go to kill an npc which is the same as hundreds of other npcs in the map...

4. I have reached CBD. The story is neither good or bad, because it does not exist. Every thing out there, organizations, citizens, governments, soildiers, has no life. The only thing that exist in this game are augments, gears and weapons. I like them actually, but when they become the center and purpose of the game, that means a very interesting cyberpunk set up is wasted.

reviewText:
This isn't even close to a Syndicate remake.

Using real time as a resource management bottleneck is probably the dumbest thing I have ever seen in an action rts. Forcing me to wait real life hours so I can equip my guys made me stop playing. This isn't Farmville, wtf is this ♥♥♥♥.

The action isn't even that important because you will always be underequipped in addition to being outnumbered (because of said bottleneck). Instead the game forces you to play it like a real time stealth tactical game, which then suffers from several UI restrictions.

The presentation is also forgettable, which in summary means you can safely skip this game.

reviewText:
Reading the reviews i can only agree with some of the comparisons, particularly to Syndicate. The 3rd cyberpunk world looks incredibly like the old syndicate games with a few brilliant extras.

First of all you play in a city where civilians roam, and the police patrol. Pull a gun out in the streets and you'll be arrested if not shot in the spot. Highjack people to clone then to improve your agents abilities. Go for a full assualt or stealthly hack and silent kill your way through bases to get your objective.

There remains to be a Role Play element as well. Agents can be upgraded with skills, weapons can be researched for a price or gambled by equiping it to an agent to use straight away, but risk losing it if they die. Build your company and be ready for the assualt!

reviewText:
This game reeks of slopiness.
The load times are painfully long.
The game stutters on perfectly adequate systems.
Almost all the missions I've played thus far have consisted of sneaking or fighting your way through an enemy base and then going through a door.
Pathfinding and agent movement is terrible so you'll regularly find yourself getting spotted because your character did something dumb.
Agents regularly simply ignore your commands, getting you killed.
You can't tell for certain whether you're behind cover or not.
It's 2016 and people in this game are still trying to shoot each other through the walls and floor.I could probably go on but a laundry list of flaws doesn't make for a very good review just like it doesn't make for a very good game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A non-biased quick look @ the game:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J5klEsX93ek

Fans of the original Amiga version of 'Syndicate' will love this. Satellite Reign is a real-time, class-based strategy game, set in an open-world cyberpunk city. You command a group of 4 agents through rain-soaked, neon-lit streets, where the law is the will of mega-corporations. Use your agents to sneak, shoot, steal, and sabotage your way up the corporate ladder, and take control of the most powerful monopoly of all time.

Each of your agents can be tailored toward your favoured play-style, while still maintaining their own unique specialisations. Shape your team into an offensive war machine, or an elite covert spec-ops outfit, and take the open-world city as your own. - Highly Recommended!

reviewText:
The game is cool and I give it a 7/10 where at least 2 points are because of nostalgia.

Gameplay is a bit weak and maybe too easy (not sure yet since only played a couple of hours) because it's simply easier to run away and wait until the alarms cool down than confronting enemies.

The city is huge with a complicated power/data network for cameras and terminals that pretty much conditions all the gameplay.
I think they should have implemented a minigame for the hacking/hardwiring instead of a tier of difficulty levels to be able to hack them.

The teleport system is also lame, they should let you use the roads to drive/ride cars or public transport instead.

reviewText:
Satellite Reign is the perfect example of a game that it worth more than the sum of its parts. The world and story are rich and deep. There is almost no story telling but you do feel like you progress into a story you create yourself.

Every gameplay systems are well thought and well put together. The skill and augmentation systems works perfectly with the few objects you can interact in the world. The combat is kinda meh but rewarding and challenging.

I guess that technically speaking the game could use some optimization.

After you finish the tutorial you are free to decide what to do and how to do it. I spent literally hours to carefully craft plans for a full stealth mission. Of course it would rarely go well and the mission would either end up in messy success or in a general retreat.
Overall the game is immense fun. A full cyberpunk city of fun. I am not too familiar with the old Syndicates games but Satelite Reign is a good game in its own rights. I wish they release some extra districts or cities via DLC or that they give us some development tools to mod it ourselves.

----------------8<-------------[ cut here ]------------------

Editing my review to tone it down a little bit.

I am still having great fun with the game and I still recommend it heartidly BUT be warned that there are indeed a lot of bugs between you and the endgame and I can now understand why some people would give it a bad review.
Character get stuck randomly or get under the map etc. One bug in particular is preventing me from getting 100 achivements. This is bothering me way too much that it should be.

reviewText:
Maybe it gets good. Thing is, I couldn't get passed the tutorial without it (at worst) glitching out on me or (at best) leaving me in limbo and not knowing what to do. When a tutorial is like that then I just don't want to play the main game, Life is too short and it sends out a real danger signal. I don't have the time to invest in games that are not user-friendly.

I don't mean easy, I mean intuitive and clear.

Danger signs were there when the tutorial wanted me to draw a weapon. I did, but it kept asking me to draw my gun like an inverted ED-209. After a bit of walking around - right up to a guard who didn't react -a gun sight appeared and I somehow managed to shoot my opponent.

The tutorial didn't recognise the guard was dead (I was still being asked to draw my weapon). The exit was locked. A pop up making some quasi-sarcastic comment about this was covered by another pop up asking me to draw my gun.

So, unable to get through the door and unsure of how to even get through the tutorial, I quit and wrote this.

Sure, this is almost likely my fault as I am sure I did something wrong. Or maybe there is a clear and simple control for opening doors.  But kinda it's not my problem. A tutorial should convey the basics of a game to any and every user. When it doesn't then it is just off-putting.

reviewText:
It is hard to admit but I can not recommend this game. I loved Syndicate and enjoy this game but it tries so hard to steal my enjoyment away.

Firstly, the load times are extreme. It actually loads twice before even showing the menu. By the time I get into a save file I could have already nuked a town of Ghouls in Fallout 4.

Second, it always crashes. Load a game... Crash. Fast travel... Lag... then Crash. Save game... Crash. I just want to play for more then 20 minutes at a time.

In conclusion, I will keep trying to play because there is nothing else like it out there. But if you didn't really love the real Syndicate this one probobly isn't worth the frustration.

reviewText:
As a huge fan of syndicate wars (hell I had a muriel based on some of the artwork drawn on my wall) I was excited to say the least when i heard its spiritual successor was going to be released by members of the original dev team. I was disappointed when I got my hands on the fruits of their labour. Don't get me wrong the graphics are decent, as are aspects of the gameplay, but the finished product had some bugs (incompletable missions etc) and was quite expensive considering it felt quite short in comparison to syndicate wars. The game play quickly becomes quite repetitive as there isn't much variety in terms of missions once you've completed the first area of play. In syndicate wars you could play through as both the goodies and the baddies, here no such luck.

If you want a bit of cyberpunk action you can dip in and out of then as they've worked out some of the kinks and the price has dropped, it could be worth a look. If however like me you wanted to relive you're miss spent youth, I'd probably give it a miss. Syndicate Wars it ain't. 5/10

reviewText:
Maybe it gets good. Thing is, I couldn't get passed the tutorial without it (at worst) glitching out on me or (at best) leaving me in limbo and not knowing what to do. When a tutorial is like that then I just don't want to play the main game, Life is too short and it sends out a real danger signal. I don't have the time to invest in games that are not user-friendly.

I don't mean easy, I mean intuitive and clear.

Danger signs were there when the tutorial wanted me to draw a weapon. I did, but it kept asking me to draw my gun like an inverted ED-209. After a bit of walking around - right up to a guard who didn't react -a gun sight appeared and I somehow managed to shoot my opponent.

The tutorial didn't recognise the guard was dead (I was still being asked to draw my weapon). The exit was locked. A pop up making some quasi-sarcastic comment about this was covered by another pop up asking me to draw my gun.

So, unable to get through the door and unsure of how to even get through the tutorial, I quit and wrote this.

Sure, this is almost likely my fault as I am sure I did something wrong. Or maybe there is a clear and simple control for opening doors.  But kinda it's not my problem. A tutorial should convey the basics of a game to any and every user. When it doesn't then it is just off-putting.

reviewText: This was one of the nicest surprises in the last couple years: a very athmospheric, surprisingly deep game that combines just the right depth of RTS, RPG and Stealth. Throughout the game, your playstyle can (and, sometimes, must) adapt and there are alway multiple, truly different, ways to achieve the objectives thrown at you. Add to that the well-toned amount of humor that is woven into mostly item descriptions, and you got yourself a great way to have a good time!\n\nI rarely experienced such a varied and well-thought-out game and am hoping for a sequel or DLC.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game had some harsh reviews, but for what it was meant to be - a spiritual successor of Syndicate - it did surprisingly good for the little money and time that was offered by the Kickstarter.
I think the authors hoped to receive more and I was kind of sceptical about this title.
But it worked out! Not without issues. NOWHERE near perfect. But it was fun. It didn't drag on. I liked it and
even hoped it would be a little longer. But overall I am happy that this game was created and I would kickstart the second game right away!

It has this nice dystopian feel, heavy cyberpunk, but the story is on the light side. It's more about tackling different areas, planning your way in and out or making sure you can efficiently eliminate all the threats.

I'd personally give this game a 7/10 score, but if you don't care for the old titles or particularly enjoy the setting, you can drop 2 points.

I know I had fun to the end of the game. While I couldn't finish all the AAA games that came out last years, which should say something. I am torn, so I just suggest reading forums. The issues go way beyond what I could cover in this review anyway, but I still do not regret this at all. I just think it's worth it :)
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is my first review. I guess I was that disappointed with this game.

I really wanted to like SR, as I have been a fan of Bullfrog's Syndicate since the 90s. But I got frustrated really fast and had to push myself to finish it (and only after boosting my agents with some cfg tweaks).

The game can be a bit addictive at first and it does have its moments, but I found the experience, as a whole, lacking and underwhelming.

(1) The world is visually nice. The graphics, atmosphere and lighting are all great. But my first and biggest gripe is that you rarely get to see this vibrant world, because 95% of the time you have to be in tactical mode (World Scan) in order to see objectives and targets etc.

(2) My second biggest issue is with the mission design. While the theoretical" choice to approach missions either via stealth or direct conflict is nice
date: the game pretty much forces you into stealth
recommended: which is more like Invisible Inc than Syndicate to be honest.\n\nOpen war is out of the question since enemies spawn endlessly and are stronger
hoursPlayed: unlike the original Syndicate which was all about mayhem and being a superior badass agent. I found that agents' damage was inferior to the enemies and lackluster (except for a few guns later on
voteText: e.g. cannons). Also agent survivability is inferior
helpfulPercent: even when using cover. I found myself dieing constantly while being unable to kill enemy soldiers fast enough. What's funny is that the same soldier was doing a lot better when not hijacked
votesHelpful:
as if hijacking reduces the damage and survivability of units?!

Other problems include:

(3) Getting into cover was a problem
votesTotal:
since the click indicator is small and finicky (unlike XCOM for example). I died many times just trying to get into cover.

(4) Too much micro-management and keybinds: I found myself skipping or nor using many skills as it got overwhelming in real time combat.

(5) Path-finding issues like agents or enemies sometimes getting stuck in terrain.

(6) Performance issues: FPS dips

<1080p res).

(7) Missions bugging out and not finishing even after completion.

(8) Missions getting repetitive after a while.

(9) Very annoying "can't save" alert.

I just hope these things get fixed!"

reviewText:
Positive:

-music from Lazerhawk
-great atmosphere from all the little details thrown into the background of the city

Negative:

-Post-Cyberpunk setting that's barely explored
-no maps inside the buildings you infiltrate
-combat is a cluster-f
-no basic AI for your four units

Feels like a great start to a good game, but there are obvious holes where content should have been and not implemented for one reason or another. Don't by this game unless you really liked the original Syndicate games.

reviewText:
This is a good game, HOWEVER, the speed in which the game plays is horrid.

I know that the Devs are working hard/researching on ways to make it run faster, but as of now, it's choppy.

Performance aside, like any game around here, you start with nothing but a pistol. As the game progresses, you earn a rifle, then you upgrade your skills so that you are harder to kill. You can clone your teammates with stats from a gaurd that you stole (Literally stole). Everything in that game is technology.

You have a Soldier (Whose Mr./Ms. Bad-A tank), a Support (Mr./Ms. field medic with stims that slow the world down), a Hacker (Gets you the money and blinds the camera feeds) and a Infiltraitor (Cloak and dagger lady/man). These four are your Corporate Espionage" team. You steal from others and claim it for yourself. Oh
date: and you can do bank heists
recommended: but remember to take all of your team through the doors for a lot of cash.\n\nAll in all
hoursPlayed: until the Devs ramp up the processing speed

reviewText:
This is a wonderful game! it is such a good idea, such polished graphics... there is so much to look at all over the neo-noir place. Did you ever play digimon world 3? if so, you can kinda realize the feeling im talking about but without all the sheity backtracking and grindfest.

the idea of making your characters immortal by successive clonning is just brilliant.  please disconsider how they look like something out of a disney villain plot. progression is kinda str8 forward, but hey, this is a minor issue and the game is still very enjoyable characterwise.

so why the negative review you may be thinking...

well... this game does not run like poop. no no no no! how would they, the developers, do that? they could do better :D

quite frankly, i never thought a game could be so underoptimized. Im not talking about some fps clunkiness, no no no!

reviewText: This was one of the nicest surprises in the last couple years: a very athmospheric, surprisingly deep game that combines just the right depth of RTS, RPG and Stealth. reviewText:
This game had some harsh reviews, but for what it was meant to be - a spiritual successor of Syndicate - it did surprisingly good for the little money and time that was offered by the Kickstarter.
I think the authors hoped to receive more and I was kind of sceptical about this title.
But it worked out! Not without issues. NOWHERE near perfect. But it was fun. It didn't drag on. I liked it and
even hoped it would be a little longer. But overall I am happy that this game was created and I would kickstart the second game right away!

It has this nice dystopian feel, heavy cyberpunk, but the story is on the light side. It's more about tackling different areas, planning your way in and out or making sure you can efficiently eliminate all the threats.

I'd personally give this game a 7/10 score, but if you don't care for the old titles or particularly enjoy the setting, you can drop 2 points.

I know I had fun to the end of the game. While I couldn't finish all the AAA games that came out last years, which should say something. I am torn, so I just suggest reading forums. The issues go way beyond what I could cover in this review anyway, but I still do not regret this at all. I just think it's worth it :)

reviewText:
For a tactical game, this one deals a really bad hand:
- ABOVE ALL: broken AI
- no ability to rotate the game camera
- saturated color and heavy bloom make it difficult to see what's going on
- no 'tactial map' or 'active pause' feature that would help plan and execute the assaults on heavily guarded areas
- it just doesn't have that 'thing' that would make you yearn for more...

A word on broken AI, because this is what eventually made me put the game away.
The game teaches you  about cone of visions of the enemies. Each NPC ( be it a soldier, a drone or a camera ), sports a 'flashlight' sort of thing that shows where it's looking and how to avoid it.
A key thing when it comes to sneaking past them, which the game stronly encourages you to do.
But they don't work - as a matter of fact the only check the game seems to make when checking if you're seen by an enemy is a distance check.

So after a number of failed attempts to sneak past a few guards in one of the protected areas, I gave up.

Gonna wait for when those issues are fixed and play then, but right now, I don't recommend this game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nCombat isn't where it needs to be and since that's something you'll be doing a lot of, I think it's a pretty big deal when the combat is as dull and boring as it is right now.  It's a matter of sinking down behind cover and witteling away at each other.  The lack of a 'pause' action is a TERRIBLE design choice as well.  It's needed when the enemies just sit there and spam attacks endlessly, not really using any tactics beyond that.  Controlling four players with unique abilities and each having their own 'niche' to fill during a combat encounter makes for a more frustrating experience than a fun one sadly.

reviewText:
To be honest I am quite disappointed with the purchase. There is probably a very good reason why, even the people who gave this game a positive review their average play time on record is 20 hours or less…

Cons

With the inability of the ai to auto fire let alone provide overwatch/support, this game is 100% a stealth game, scratch the strategy and action tags...  if your found out, you have to run, out of the restriction zone and hide, chances are one of your team will die from derping it out with a wall and the 5 seconds revive or die timer will run out along with your short burst run timer.

I will try to keep playing this. try...

reviewText:
Just a couple of brief comments:
Overall feeling is - that the game was originally something like an amateur mod-like type and later somehow was transformed into a full fledged project.

Visuals are ambiguous -  nice mocap and models on one hand but weird colors and eclectic art style on the other.
Gameplay is plain, straightforward and very monotonous - there is no place for tactics or fun just overflood enemies with cursor fire. Stealth is an option in theory but on practice it is just a dull and repetative movement from cover to cover.
UI is bulky and IMO overcomplicated which in conjunction with primitive gameplay gives a somewhat inconsistent and even frustrting experince.

To sum it up -  Unfortunately it is not a new Syndicate" as somebody saying. Just a very mediocre game which is going to sell itself trying to mimic classic titles.
Definitely would not recommend it."

reviewText:
As an old Syndicate fan I wanted to like this game, but like many games these days I ran into technical issues that put me off right from the get-go. The game is clearly pretty badly optimized, as switching between Low and Ultra settings on my rather high-end PC barely did anything to my framerate. Disabling SSR (?) boosted my framerate from 30 to about 80, but considering the type of game it is and the quality of visuals, it should be running much better. I'm glad the game supports 120hz, but apparently it can't quite run at those framerates.

I also quickly got frustrated with the unintuitive interface which seemed to get in the way. I'm sure with time I could get used to it, but as I didn't find things responding to my controls quite like I expected - if at all - it just wasn't worth the hassle for me when there are many other games out that don't have these problems.

Games need to get their basics right because first impressions make all the difference. I'm not going to experience the rest of the game if I'm put off by so many other things.

reviewText:
Okay, so let's talk.

I liked Syndicate, and this game inspires a lot of the same feelings. Love the modern, lush depiction of what once was a sterile, dystopian society writ in abstract by the limits of graphical fidelity. I enjoy that they've tried to keep a significant portion of the game's variety of approach. I liked the small unit tactics, of the original, but most especially liked that you could complete most (indeed, eventually almost all) missions with the application of stupid amounts of boom.

But that was then, and this is now. So let's talk about how the game plays, right?

Pathfinding? Yeah, it's there, but it's not 100%. You'll have agents (as I just did, yet again) who fail to pathfind around the end of a chainlink fence, and instead end up dancing a pathfinding failure as they're gunned down in realtime, with you more or less helpless until you notice that they're spazzing instead of fighting back.

Skill and character customization? Yeah, it's there, and the game adds its own wrinkle of sorts in the form of variable clone stats that you can take advantage of. It's not a major feature, but it adds a little edge. Of course, the developers fail to telegraph how certain design choices will play out vis-a-vis the support character - the lynchpin of the entire game and squad (but don't sprint).

The decision to opt for a triggered ability instead of a tactical pause sounds good, at first - it did to me too, and then you add cover for a more tactical game? Hell, the original Syndicate never had cover, so how could they get it wrong?

Well.. this is where the train starts to leave the tracks.

See, in the original Syndicate, you could mod your agents hormonal levels, in order to boost them" later by "nerfing them" early on. Effectively

reviewText:
It saddens me that I find myself giving this game a bad review.  However, it is so poorly optimised that frame rates drop as low as 10-15 fps at times.  This is seemingly random, as there doesn't appear to be any particular graphical effect, or very busy area that causes it, and dropping my resolution and turning off all effects and setting the graphics to low also doesn't resolve the problem.  I may not have the most high-end machine, but it can run games like Elite: Dangerous and Alien Isolation on ultra, and achieve 60 fps with no problem, and GTA V on medium at 60 FPS.  This game should not be taxing my GPU so much that it will drop below 20 FPS even on low graphics settings.

Additionally, there are areas where the cover system just does not work. Combine that with a clunky interface and you will often be frustrated by one of your agents running out into the open during a firefight, after you tried to command them to move to a different cover-location.  I could normally work round something like this, but Satellite Reign is so unforgiving that there is absolutely no room for mistakes.

There are suggestions that switching to the nightly build of the game might relieve some of these issues, but not so far.  I would wait a while for the devs to do better QA and optimise the damn thing before buying.  If they sort these issues out, or at least either resolve the varying frame rate, or lock it to 30fps, I will gladly change my review to recommend, as it looks beautiful, even if it runs like a dog dragging it's hole across the carpet, the sound design is excellent and the fluff that I've seen so far is great too.

reviewText:
I was thrilled to see this game come out of early access. I heavily considered backing it during its Kickstarter campaign due to my love of cyberpunk, but had already contributed money to other projects. The game does a some things right, particularly with its setting, but fails in so many other areas that I cannot recommend it.

I've only played the game for 3 hours and felt like I was fighting the controls the entire time.

- Often I'd place a sniper in a high position only to watch her refuse to take a shot at anyone below once the combat start. Occassionally she would run down an elevator to join the other combatants, getting gunned down the entire way. There's no way she didn't have line of sight to at least one of the army of enemies below her.

- Any time I tried a stealth kill with a silenced weapon, the character would run up to arms length with the target, who would trun around at the approach and initiate a gun fight. Outside of the tutorial these stealth kills never once worked.

- Characters I'd moved around for a wide flank would end up getting flanked themselves by one of the enemies that seem to come from every single direction. Not so much a problem in itself, but while I was focusing on my other two operatives, the two moving around to flank would completely ignore anyone shooting them in the face from 5 ft away unless expressly told to return fire. There is no toggle I know of for characters to automatically return.

- Weapons must be manually drawn, meaning I needed to pull out the weapons for each of my characters if they got into a fire fight. Clicking on enemy would not automatically instruct the characters to pull out their weapons, which made absolutely zero sense.

I could go on, but these represent that major annoyances encountered in just the first few hours. The above, however, does not include the bugs.

- I crashed to desktop every single time I tried to exit to main menu or load within the game.

- Cars in the game could be seen doing sharp donuts in the middle of a high security facility. Cars also seem to pass right until my operatives, who launch over them and back onto the ground as if nothing happened.

- Enemies spawned from alarms return to their doors and run in place agains the door, sometimes stacking up to 3-5 enemies stacked on eachother fruitlessly running into metal for no reason.

Satellite Reign is severely flawed both mechanically and operationally and still feels like an early access/unfinished product. The game desperately needs a pause feature, more information on chances to hit and the benefits of cover, stealth kills that actually work, info on character line of sight, and so much more. This is a tactical game that removes your ability to operate tactically and as such needs a lot of work.

reviewText:
What a terrible disappointment. Perhaps nostalgia got the better of me with this one.

The game had me so hyped that it was going to be a worthy followup to Bullfrogs Syndicate. Honestly I dont know how they could be mentioned in the same sentence. This game seems to be more about hacking, than the four cyborgs with massive miniguns tearing up a city I remember from my youth. I just seem to have walk around the map right clicking on ATMs.

Played it for an hour and got bored with the clunky controls. The stealth mechanics are a joke and the combat is uninspired.

Really glad i didn't by on release and waited for the Lunar New Year Sale. £7 you pay your money and take the chance. £23  way way overpriced for this indie nostalgia cash in.

reviewText: I don't like the RTS feel of this game. I feel like it robs me of a great deal of control I would expect as a team leader of a bunch of elite runners. Instead I have a crew of knuckleheads that blaze away at suboptimal targets or take a weird path that ends up aggroing a bunch more security guards to the party (not recommended). Morally...this game sucks! Do I really have to murder my way through just about every mission? Heck, some of the missions I need to advance are literally assassinations. Not cool. Sorry, it may be a game, but I am not interested.

reviewText:
After 15 of gameplay as much as I'd love to, I cannot wholeheartedly recommend this game in it's current state.

The atmosphere is there, features are there, feels very syndicate-y, but the alerting amount of bugs and the infuriatingly broken AI, not to mention the quirky, non responding controls makes it unenjoyable.

Give them a bit more time to polish and to kill the swarm of bugs, then check it out, because syndicate is back and you'll love it when it's working as it's supposed to.

reviewText:
Currently this game has a ton of positive reviews. However, upon further inspection, a good majority of those reviews are just short statements behind nolstalgia goggles. I did not play the original Syndicate, so I have no attachment to the original game. Though, I do love squad based games, especially if it is in a tactical nature. That being said, does the game deliver? Sadly no. In all honesty, this game only really has one pro and that's the visual aspect.

Right off the bat the thing that'll draw you in first is obviously the world and setting. It's a beautifully crafted cyberpunk city, that's fairly big and open for you to explore and play around in. The lighting is top notch, the signs shine bright with plenty of ambience that makes you appreciate the work put into the small details. Stuff that fades out into the back drop of most games has you zooming in to see the little details, such as MeGaCo Pizza, Noodle Boy, and various other little shops I wouldn't notice otherwise if they weren't detailed to the smallest prop. Of the many complaints you'll find of this game, visually and aesthetically will likely never be mentioned in a negative light.

The game world itself is fairly large on top of looking gorgeous, and it's all alive. From cars zooming past, to random civilians moving about, and even what appears to be squatters in certain parts of the city are all there to give this locale a heartbeat. The music isn't even all that outstanding or standout, but it at least is appropriate to the setting to even further give things a pulse. However, it being alive doesn't mean it has a personality to match. Nothing is explained in the game world, aside from evil corporation(s)
date: take them down". And that's basically it when you're thrown into it. Maybe I missed it as well
recommended: but was the locale ever really even explained? What city is this? Is it based off any real one? Is it a made up one for the game? Does it even have a NAME? Each section just has a generic label: Downtown
hoursPlayed: Industrial

it's freaking bad. The tutorial in the dossier is as follows:

Cloning
Your agents clone bodies from civilians.
And that is it. Seriously? It's the equivalent of a combat tutorial ONLY saying "Combat: it's where you kill people."

In general a good majority of things aren't explained whatsoever in this game. You will get more information in the short description of the game and the setting as a whole from the Steam store page. After the tutorial you're just tossed into the world with no description of what to do aside from your "Mission Control" tab in the menu. Even then all that it really gives you are pings around the map of what to do next. But what end goals are you planning in the scheme of things? Who are you doing it for? What is the overall purpose?

I can't even say the game makes up for it with gameplay. There is no pause

reviewText:
This Review is based off the short time I played the game.

I'd Like to love this game I would, But for me this game was extremely Buggy.

The two major bugs I had are as follows.

Units when in combat would stop doing anything and would just stand up in the open and waggle their gun left to right even after being given orders. This even happened to the enemies on occasion.

The other major bug I had was everytime I loaded my save I could not give any orders to my units at all, The only way to fix this was to just keep reloading till it worked.

When I did get to play the game was fun, But moments of it working were far and few between.

I Have refunded this game as of right now, But I will most likely pick it back up in the future when a sale happens.

reviewText:
Have to run it at 960x600 at otherwise lowest graphics settings to get anything approaching decent FPS.

Criticism 1 here: Even as is i see many effects on that do not need to be on, weather effects, shader effects, etc. If there were more options the game could be tuned to run fine on higher resolutions.

Criticism 2: Sadly, at that resolution the UI is completely unusable, since the fonts are tiny and blurred into smudgy messes, and you're expected to make use of buttons that are mere pixels across.

If they fixed either of those, it be good to play, but as it is, if you have a weak-ish machine, i cannot recommend this game.

reviewText:
I kickstarted this, Sigh.

When the developers brainstormed ideas for Satelite reign, they chose poorly from a list of ideas that ranged from great to attrocious.

The feel of Satelite riegn is amateurish, in all areas. From the point that this is more a fan-made mod than a professionally produced game.

GAMEPLAYTutorial - lacklustre, I was stuck for 10 minutes.
Beginning middle and endgame (according to other reviews) is unbalanced, repetitive, and dull. I couldn't play it for more than half an hour before I was bored out of my mind.

DESIGNInterface - overly complex, with clickable tiny icons less than 3mm accross (2560x1600)
Dialog Feedback - dialog and briefings pushed up to the far right of the screen away from your eyes (2560x1600)
Information - Unneccessary bordering and small fonts make reading difficult (2560x1600)
Map - Always on, draggable size map is a welcome addition.
Iconography - Badly designed, and subject to miscommunication.
+ more

AESTHETICSStyle - using 0101 graphics to represent hacking hasn't been used since BUllfrog's syndicate era, and they didnt use it either.
Art - Tronesque is boring. Its been done before. Is there nothing else? *syndicate didn't use neon*
Backgrounds - Neon text on black. No comment.
+more

MECHANICSInteractions - they use unconventional methods of interaction (point and HOLD instead of click).
+more

LORESomething something ruthless corporate business something something kill. The introduction is sparse.
There is a homage to syndicate but it is more plagerism than creating something new.
+ more

reviewText:
As a fan of the old syndicate i really tried to like this game but couldn't. Hearing this was the true sequel for 93-syndicate I even skipped all the reviews and everything and just bought this game (and that's really unlike me).

PROs
+When everything is working this game is great fun and damn is it nervewrecking exciting

CONs
-The game is plagued with A LOT of bugs for example these are my most recent bugs;
*Trying to shoot a security camera my units just keep on trying to run towards it, and the camera just keeps sending more and more enemy back ups
*Quest character got stuck inside a building so I couldn't save game and lost 3 hours of progression (since I went on doing other stuff naively expecting the bug would fix itself)
*sometimes units just aim stuff when you ask them to shoot stuff.
*ALWAYS your units keep shooting enemies even if they are behind a wall, wasting all the ammo
*sometimes doors get bugged and won't open, this ruined my run when I tried to escape from enemy stronghold but the door wouldn't open (sometimes the AI gets stuck in these too just stuck in the running animation towards the door)
-Graphics make me feel like there is something wrong with my eyes (the glow espesially in the menus)
-Game explains itself very badly, for example; I still have no clue that what I am looting from the dead security guards. I have no idea what the number with the icon next to my money means. And since this isn't so wide spread game, I NEVER found any help from google.
-Controlling units is REALLY clumsy.
-Quests get really repetitive.
-Researchable stuff is quite unimpressive, if I remember right it was better in original syndicate (at least in original you could actually see the robotic parts you installed into your agents)
-The world is cool but there is nothing to do besides the missions.

I CANNOT BELIEVE THERE IS NO EARLY ACCES SIGN ON THE STOREPAGE OF THIS GAME!

There are times that I REALLY enjoy playing this game, but I won't recommend it with all the bugs and bad design choises. This game could have been so much more..

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game shouldn't be released on early access yet. It's in very early days and while it looks pretty, the graphics are highly UNoptimized and the game extremely buggy.

That said, the atmosphere created is incredible. Such a rich expansive cyberpunk world.

I cannot wait for the finished product, but as it is this is just a complete tease. Right now it's more of a tech demo. You can see where development is going but it's a long way from completion.

Keep patiently waiting, it'll be worth it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While I love the concept of the game (I've played original Syndicate games as a teenager) and I see a great potential in this title, unfortunately it's not there yet. This game is very badly optimized and runs at average ~8 FPS for most of the time on my PC, in lowest possible settings. In highest possible setting - it's almost the same. I had no problems in getting AC: Unity or ME: Shadow of Mordor to run at 30 FPS in full HD on mid settings.

Still, if your PC is maxed out, I've heard you can get it to run at 20 or even 30 FPS. It's still not good, but playable.

Best, Pawel

PS. My PC: i7-4700MQ, 8GB ram, Nvidia GTX 760M.

reviewText:
This is a review that I will constantly update as I play more and get more feels for the game. But since everyone downvotes it because they don't agree with me I might as well write this: WORST GAEM EVURZ LOL DYE NUBS because the voting system on steam is more ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t than this game.

The game suffers from several flaws that I feel could make the game a lot better:
1. The enemies have two sets of flashlights, White and Yellow. When Yellow they are looking for you, but haven't found you yet, and White, everything that isn't yellow, all from not knowing about you to outright attacking you (This can be annoying as you never know if they're running towards you to kill you, or running past you.
2. You can target enemies that your agent cannot attack properly, making them shoot at an impenetrable wall all for nothing. Another thing that is a real bother about your agents and shooting is how, while there is a way to make them move and attack as they meet targets, there are no ways of making them stay in cover, and shoot at any target, you have to micromanage it so incredibly deep.
3. A lot of the game is based on you having to micromanage everything, from setting up every agent, choosing their targets, using their abilities, and ressurecting fallen agents, all while under fire from multiple locations, having enemies come from all directions and leaving you to either stay where you are (Which mostly ends up killing you) or running up against the enemy in a hail of bullets to get a better position. Neither is very fun to choose.
4. When in a gun fight you want to get into cover as fast as possible, so if you happen to get your agents not standing in cover, you'll want to mark them all and click on the closest cover, right? well this game punishes you for it because actually clicking for them to get in cover or just standing next to cover is pixel-close, easily making your agents just wander around in a damn ugly dance.
5. Movement is very forced, your agents don't change direction or turn corners with anything but ugly drunken stagger, whenever they reach a corner they stop for a split second before shambling into the new direction.
5.1 The movement get's extra terrible when trying to Stealth Kill enemy guards, due to if the guards turn a corner your agent will first run to the place they were when you clicked them (Even if it's out of the way), then they will take the same drunken stagger around the same corner the guard did, and then they go after the guard! (And hope that it didn't turn any more corners as it'll make even more drunken staggering on your side!)

The game is very unforgiving, there are security cameras everywhere, guards randomly patrolling, something simple like hacking an ATM machine can become a fight where the game throws everything and the kitchen sink at you, and the ATM hacks are giving such small rewards you begin questioning the games intent. You always wish you have 4 hackers and 4 assassins just so you can kill everything without being heard and hack everything because your hacker needs to be in so many places at once.

So far I can say that if you want a casual game, Don't get it.
If you like RPGs where you have soooo much options (you're able to Force some actions, like hacking, to happen, but without the right skills your agents can die to RNG and alert nearby enemies to his location). But you also need to think extremely Strategical as you are constantly surrounded by enemies and have to think fast, even if you've planned greatly. You also need to micromanage the game on an insanely deep level that I've explained earlier in the review.

HOWEVER, the game feels incredibly great when you have managed to get past a certain objective which has given you problems for a while.

BUT, the game seems to punish both Guns Blazing and Stealth styles as stealth is very easy to screw up and requires a lot of work, most of the time by one or two agents leaving the other two to just stand and hope not to get outflanked while you're busy. Likewise the Guns Blazing option gives you a better feeling for loosing, since you're going in blazing! It's to be expected if you screw up, but it's still easy to be outflanked, outnumbered, not having the opportunity to shoot down alarming guards, and you're having to out-micromanage a computer. ♥♥♥♥ that!

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. I loved Syndicate Wars. It is one of my favorite games on Playstation. Unfortunately, Satellite Reign is nowhere near as good. This game has potential, but it will not be reached until Satellite Reign II, if that ever comes out.

The thing I absolutely hated in Satellite Reign is mouse controls. The agents feel unresponsive sometimes, certain actions are very hard to get to activate at maximum camera height. It's also hard to get the agents to stand exactly where you need for the same reasons. Overall, the controls feel laggy and not precise enough.

This makes the game unplayable at times thanks to the fact that it is real-time. I was struggling to control my agents and get them to do exactly what I wanted them to in fights where more than two enemies were involved. Then there's the fact that the game doesn't save your location or certain game state elements. When you reload a saved game it simply places your agents at the neares respawn location. Basically, you can't try a certain approach and when it doesn't work just reload and try again. You'll have to run back from the damn spawn point, get all agents into positions, wait for the enemies to move into their positions... Basically, the game actively punishes you for reloading and tries to force you to live with the consequences of failed actions.

This could work for you, but it doesn't for me. I could ignore this if the rest of the game was tight, but it's just not.

Enemies keep respawning almost instantly if you take them out silently, makes clearing compounds stealthily to try and make a path for your Hacker completely pointless. It all boils down to two approaches: sneak past all the security cameras and guards or fight your way to the objective and back. If at least the missions had a bit more variety to them, but most of the missions in the first grid are just the same routine over and over again with nothing to do between them except for trying to get better clones.

Unless you're REALLY into Syndicate and want something to scratch that itch, go ahead and grab Satellite Reign. Otherwise, I don't recommend it.

reviewText:
I've played Satellite Reign for about 12 hours (6 hours weren't counted due to offline mode).

Even though I was a huge fan of Syndicate (Wars), I never kickstarted this because the kickstarter seemed to promote fancy graphics over gameplay. When they came out of Early Access I bought the game because I was curious and left me pleasantly surprised.

The game feels very much Syndicaty to me. You roam around a city doing cyborgy stuff, and there's plenty to do. It can be quite challenging, and you more or less get to set your own pace. In a way SR does some things better than the original that inspired this title; the things you do in the world make a lot more sense and serve you well, and the agent specialization and skill system work really well.

That said, the game isn't without its flaws. Combat can be frustrating (due to technical issues; responsiveness of agents, pathfinding, enemy spawning, illogical terminal placements, etc), the other side of the coin means that it can be incredibly rewarding when you /do/ manage to complete a mission.

(TLDR) Despit its flaws, it's still a really interesting game that plays unlike anything else that was released in recent years, and well worth the price they're asking (which at this time of writing is below 30 euro). But if you're someone who gets frustrated easily, you may want to skip this one.

reviewText: I'm struggling to stop playing this game. I remember spending many an afternoon after school playing its spritual predecessor Syndicate, and then many years wishing someone would make a more modern version. This is everything I hoped for and more. The genre is a little hard to pin down - perhaps a mix of Deus Ex, X-Com (but realtime) and something like Commandos - but that doesn't really do it justice. It's a large open-world, with many different possible paths - pure stealth, stealth killing/assassination or plain frontal-assault. Combat isn't usually plan A, but it makes a very fun plan B if your carefully laid plan goes to pot. It's had me on the edge of my seat during missions so many times and I'm probably only two-thirds of the way through. I suspect when I finish it I'll have another go and make some different choices too.

reviewText:
There's an obvious question to ask about Satellite Reign:

I loved Syndicate - will I like Satellite Reign?
The simple answer is yes, from the very moment you get to the main menu, the style and feeling of Syndicate suffuses this game, even down to the fact that the UI sounds brought back warm fuzzy feelings to me.

It's not just an updated reskin of Syndicate though - fundamentals are there, but Satellite Reign feels a little more sophisticated and mature, as you would hope after over a decade in which for the has become more sophisticated and refined as a whole.

But this leads me to a second, prehaps less obvious question:

I loved Commandos - will I like Satellite Reign?
The simple answer is again yes. In case you're not aware, Commandos[en.wikipedia.org] was a stealth heavy game where you had a group of soliders each with a unique set of skills. You'd need to use these skills in coordination to complete the missions, and the same is very much true of Satellite Reign.

Fortunately for me, I loved both of the above games and therefore I can't get enough of Satellite Reign :)

reviewText: This is almost everything I've ever wanted out of a Shadowrun game. The combat takes some getting used to if you're used to a more turn based style, though if you do want to pause to issue orders, a skill has been added to allow a massive slowdown in time for just that purpose. That said, the depth of options and customization is surprisingly varied. You can clear things using just stealth or just combat, or go for a hybrid of the two. The number of options for getting from point A to B is also really enjoyable. Gotta make it through a door? You could cut the power, hack the door, hijack a personnel member who has access, use an explosive satchel on the door, etc. This same sense of possibility exists for just about each point of infiltrations. I very much recommend this game.
