reviewText:
Quick summary: highly recommended.
I wanted to see something like this in a long time. One of my first reviews on steam, so will just to in regular fasion.

Pros:
Amazing atmosphere, good gameplay.

What was the last game in recent N years that made you think while not being a puzzle? This can be the one. You have one of two major opportunities for any mission: bash or stealth. Though even forcing will not work for you if you go headon without using some brain. Seen some other review where people were wincing for force like never works, that is completely wrong. Force can get you through with this game, but not singlehandedly.

Heroes: nice look, some RPG system.

Stealth: Locations in game have lots of stealth attributes like Cameras/CentryTowers/Gates, but all of these can be negated by hacking/rewiring power generators or security terminals and backdoors of course.

Bruteforce: Health/Armr/Shield/Guns as usual. Bonus with environmental terrain. Enemies calling for support. And nice feature of making own army by taking enemies under control.

Video: Setting is nice hyberpunk style. I can't say it is super-duper scenery, but it is pleasant all around and it has it's nice scenery and vista points to get to. I'd prefer it being a bit less resource intensive and it being more smooth though.

Audio: Nice background fitting the setting with variations for fight/stealth/etc.

General: Has feeling of old-school games, ie Cyndicate and also Neromancer book.


Cons:
Stealth is pretty much not worth it atm, as brute forcing most of the game is easier and gives more income/benefits.

Some lack of chars management, like seldom auto-path glitches or no auto-fire feature.

Overall:
Highly recommended. I don't buy much stuff, but this thing is worth it. If you see discount -- higly recommended to aqcuire.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Squad-based Real-Time Tactics with solid Stealth/Infiltration mechanics.  It's arguably a better Shadowrun game than the Shadowrun games (the only thing it's missing is magic).

Ability/Class balance is all over the place but now that I put some thought into it, each class has its Niche other than the Soldier, who is butts.  The Support does its job pretty well with some strong group-wide passives and Scanning, the Infiltrator is a Ninja Gaiden, and the Hacker will push you through the end-game with Hijack.  The Soldier sits around and is huge I guess?  Is eventually replaced with Augmentations?

Strong visual aesthetics if you like Neon (I do).  Music is kind of bland cyber punk techno stuff.

The story is fairly bleah.  The writing is decent, though you're likely to miss most of it.  The ending is hilarious (I just got the pun).

Mission/Level design is pretty good.  Each area has multiple entry-points and the game really benefits from planning before execution.  Quests are weird as hell, though.  Like you'll break into a warehouse and then find out that you have to do something in another Zone before breaking into the warehouse again because...?

Overall, a good game.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This is basically the Commandos series in a cyberpunk style. I liked it, but it was definitely not as difficult as the Commandos series, and it didn't offer depth in the right places. Still, it was a cool game that I enjoyed playing. Here's some pro's and cons that I experienced!

Pro's Commandos style gameplay, offering a tactical strategy game with 4 (sometimes more) distinct and original characters.
Nice cyberpunk design.
Clear directions of what to do and where to go to (this tends to be pretty vague at these kind of games).
Rewarding stealth gameplay.
Multiple paths to one solution (though sometimes this is cheap - like a door that has a terminal next to it that you can hack to open it, but there's also a machine right on the other side to hardwire" it

reviewText: This game was clearly made by a bunch of passionate people who played the old syndicate and loved it. I haven't played syndicate for many long years, but I couldn't help remembering it while going through this one. The old one was repetitive as hell, and this one did improve somewhat on the recipe by adding some layer of story on top of each mission, but it's still more or less of the same gameplay mechanics throughout, peppered with upgrades and various powerups to spice it up.\n\nFor those who did not play the old Syndicate, this is a real time and squad based action game, where you control 4 agents in a futuristic cyberpunk city, reminescent of the movie Blade runner" where it's always night time and raining. Each agent has core skills common to every agent
date: and a few special skills specific to their profile (soldier / hacker / support / infiltrator). You tackle various missions spread all over a big map starting low in equipment and firepower and slowly building it up.\n\nI liked the art
recommended: the environment and the music very much
hoursPlayed: and although the AI was dumb it did not stop me from liking the game. I felt like I was playing the old game again
voteText: but having grown older I viewed this game with my 2016 eyes and experience and I think that this game is a worthy successor.\n\n[edit after some checks] actually some of the devs worked on the old syndicate so that explains why the game feels so true to its ancestor."

reviewText: Great real time tactical game. Everyone online seems to be comparing it to Bullfrog's all-time classic Syndicate". Is it Syndicate? No. Does it nail the feel? Completely. Besides have you tried playing the original Syndicate in the last 15 or so years? This game completely plays "like how I remember Syndicate played". They nailed the cyberpunk atmosphere and it draws you in quickly.\n\nThere are the occasional bugs (mainly with collision checks) which at times can be showstoppers and require reloading from a save but thankfully they're relatively few and far between. For the most part
date: the game is well polished and runs well with detail turned all the way up. The devs also did an amazing job of balancing the game. You -can- go full-out assault... but its rarely the wisest choice. People who like to spend the time to analyze approaches will be rewarded.\n\nDefinitely don't miss this game."

reviewText:
Great revival of the Syndicate Wars vibe with a solid bunch of mechanics behind it. The game encourages players to be creative and most situations can be approached in many different ways. Complemented by a wide range of equipment and upgrades, the player has an extensive toolbox to play with and after an introduction to the game's mechanics through a brief tutorial, players are allowed to freely roam the city in any way they see fit. This sense of freedom is great. The work that has been put into immersing players in this strange neon/corporate future does its job well.

Some work is still required in terms of enemy AI, which can be fooled somewhat easily at times, but overall the game can be very unforgiving of mistakes and has a good learning curve. Not once in my playthrough did a mission feel like a 'chore'. Every single bit of content was fleshed out, fun and interesting to play.

Definitely worth picking up, although I am still hoping for some expanding content. The city could be a bit larger, but that should by no means detract from the experience.

reviewText:
There's an obvious question to ask about Satellite Reign:

I loved Syndicate - will I like Satellite Reign?
The simple answer is yes, from the very moment you get to the main menu, the style and feeling of Syndicate suffuses this game, even down to the fact that the UI sounds brought back warm fuzzy feelings to me.

It's not just an updated reskin of Syndicate though - fundamentals are there, but Satellite Reign feels a little more sophisticated and mature, as you would hope after over a decade in which for the has become more sophisticated and refined as a whole.

But this leads me to a second, prehaps less obvious question:

I loved Commandos - will I like Satellite Reign?
The simple answer is again yes. In case you're not aware, Commandos[en.wikipedia.org] was a stealth heavy game where you had a group of soliders each with a unique set of skills. You'd need to use these skills in coordination to complete the missions, and the same is very much true of Satellite Reign.

Fortunately for me, I loved both of the above games and therefore I can't get enough of Satellite Reign :)

reviewText:
Pros-

Enjoyable game.  The game allows you to tackle objectives the way you want.  You can smash your way in or sneak.  I play a combination of the two.   Map design is good that it makes choices on making those objectives enjoyable.  The Art and music are fitting the game.  Nothing seems out of place.  Controls work well.  Leveling and character outfitting is well done and makes sense.

Cons-

The game play has some quirks.  Path finding issues, small problem but noticeable if not careful.  The factions act as enemies and allies at the same time.  If you hijack a person of another faction and bring them in to another factions base they will attack them, but if you alerted a faction and run into another faction will attack you as if they were on the same side. Also rare but noticeable is when your character gets stuck on terrain.

Conclusion-

Buy this game.  The issues with the game are not major and will probably get fixed with a patch.  Fun experience for me so far.

reviewText:
I was a HUGE fan of Syndicate Wars.
With this I was looking forward to reliving the gritty impact of that game...
But as it stands... I personally feel this game was not worth the money.
First, My computer meets recommended requirements and it is capable of running The Witcher III quite nicely, which I believe is a much more resource hungry game.

That said... the following bothered me so much that I don't want to play any further than the 5 hours I've put into it (SR) so far.

1. The camera only rotates a few degrees. Many times I've wanted to get a better view and was unable to do so.
2. The Ziplines seems forced and unneccesary. I find no pleasure in this feature.
3. The fast travel spoils it for me, but that's a matter of personal taste.
4. The game takes a long time to load. I've spent what feels like at least five minutes just waiting for progress bars; The satellite connection needs to be established both before and after I load a saved game? I'm not sure what this refers to but I imagine it's the process of loading the scene and all the assets... it takes a while.
And finally, when the game is up and running...
5. The frame rate is poor and the AI is erratic. I've watched a security guard run up and down the door-door stairway at least ten times for no apparent reason... and sometimes they seem to notice me when I was certain that the coast was clear.

I can appreciate the effort that went into making this games and the visual assets are quite nice to look at...But for the frustrations above, I feel like I've spent more money on this than I would have liked. The game simply doesn't feel fun. I also feel like the hype generated around this acclaimed successor is overrated.

I would not recommend buying this game.

reviewText:
A spiritual successor to syndicate that improves on the original.
Mechanistically, this is a birds-eye real time simulation of a small team of agents in a cyberpunk setting. The inspiration from bullfrog's syndicate is obvious, yet this game manages the impressive feat of improving on that original.

I absolutely love that you can approach your objective in a number of different ways... Yes, you can tool up and go in guns a-blazing, but you can also sneak in one or two agents to try and complete the mission without raising any alarms... or mind-control the right guard, or bribe a disgruntled ex-employee, send your soldier to cause a distraction on the opposite side of the compound, and so on.

bugs/issues
I have had a few issues with escorted characters sometimes getting stuck when going through vents. (as of 2015.10.25, may have been patched since).
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Enjoyed it tremendously. You explore the city sectors and its points of interest to scout out vulnerabilities and potential loot including some which are effectively part of the main mission and others which are just side quests. At any time you're free to select which one to go after next; all the while leveling your agents as well as gathering and researching equipment and augmentations to suit your playstyle. Each facility infiltration lets you go in guns blazing or more stealthily. Bribe guards to open gates. Control the chips inside enemy troops or civilians.

reviewText:
Squad-based Real-Time Tactics with solid Stealth/Infiltration mechanics.  It's arguably a better Shadowrun game than the Shadowrun games (the only thing it's missing is magic).

Ability/Class balance is all over the place but now that I put some thought into it, each class has its Niche other than the Soldier, who is butts.  The Support does its job pretty well with some strong group-wide passives and Scanning, the Infiltrator is a Ninja Gaiden, and the Hacker will push you through the end-game with Hijack.  The Soldier sits around and is huge I guess?  Is eventually replaced with Augmentations?

Strong visual aesthetics if you like Neon (I do).  Music is kind of bland cyber punk techno stuff.

The story is fairly bleah.  The writing is decent, though you're likely to miss most of it.  The ending is hilarious (I just got the pun).

Mission/Level design is pretty good.  Each area has multiple entry-points and the game really benefits from planning before execution.  Quests are weird as hell, though.  Like you'll break into a warehouse and then find out that you have to do something in another Zone before breaking into the warehouse again because...?

Overall, a good game.

reviewText:
I've been a massive fan of Syndicate and Syndicate Wars since their releases. They've consistently been some of my favorite games and I've always remembered them very fondly. Here's what's different this time:

Corporations are monolithic institutions with control over every facet of the world. The police are omnipresent, but if you get caught by them, they're just as likely to beat you and rob you as they are to arrest you. Everything you see is connected to a network which can be exploited to breach all sorts of security. Civilians are everywhere, but they don't really do anything other than walk around aimlessly and have no real purpose.

Oh...oh THE GAME! The game, right. Satellite Reign is awesome and it's an excellent Syndicate game. If you liked Syndicate you should check it out. If you loved the Syndicate games, you need to buy this one.

reviewText:
I've only been playing the game for a couple of hours, but I can only hope to get a good amount of play time out of it. This is by far one of the best games I've played lately. I watched a few trailers before and after the game's release, but was mostly just curious about it. I finally picked it up and just after the quick tutorial I was fully invested, if you aren't sure about the game I suggest watching a video of the quick tutorial to make your decision.

The game has a great art style and graphics are more than I could hope for. The gameplay is fairly simple but leaves a lot up to your own preferred play style. You can break into places guns blazing or carefully sneak in using various abilities and techniques. There is a lot of customization for your character skills and equipment, I can't wait to see what it's like further into the game. I saw a hint of co-op multiplayer on the game's website and look forward to playing it with friends.

The only downside I have with the game so far is the menu's blur effect, it throws off my vision and I try to view it as quickly as possible. There is a lot of story and interesting details to check out here, so hopefully its something you can change at some point.

reviewText:
It's time to update this review. I originally gave a thumbs down based on the early access version, which was very messy by the time. Now I'm gonna re-review it, based on the final version.

What can I say. I can finally say I'm playing the so awaited Syndicate Wars game expected for almost two decades. It isn't simply a nostalgia based game, it took the formula to another level. Syndicate games had an open world feeling way before GTA saw the day of light, despite being mission/level based.

5 Live Studio did a great job here. They inserted many features from different games to evolve the Syndicate formula.

You can play with 4 unique classes, each one with it's own speciality. Soldier is a close combat unit, as it's perks and skills relies on that. There's the support, as the name says, it's something close to Battlefield's medic. The hacker is the unity dedicated to shut down cameras, security systems, machine guns and open restricted areas doors. They also hack ATMs, allowing you to get more income. They can mind control" civilans

reviewText:
I've played Satellite Reign for about 12 hours (6 hours weren't counted due to offline mode).

Even though I was a huge fan of Syndicate (Wars), I never kickstarted this because the kickstarter seemed to promote fancy graphics over gameplay. When they came out of Early Access I bought the game because I was curious and left me pleasantly surprised.

The game feels very much Syndicaty to me. You roam around a city doing cyborgy stuff, and there's plenty to do. It can be quite challenging, and you more or less get to set your own pace. In a way SR does some things better than the original that inspired this title; the things you do in the world make a lot more sense and serve you well, and the agent specialization and skill system work really well.

That said, the game isn't without its flaws. Combat can be frustrating (due to technical issues; responsiveness of agents, pathfinding, enemy spawning, illogical terminal placements, etc), the other side of the coin means that it can be incredibly rewarding when you /do/ manage to complete a mission.

(TLDR) Despit its flaws, it's still a really interesting game that plays unlike anything else that was released in recent years, and well worth the price they're asking (which at this time of writing is below 30 euro). But if you're someone who gets frustrated easily, you may want to skip this one.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I haven't played Syndicate so my review is only going to be based on what a player new to the franchise perceived. Love the idea, some great visual tricks and an excellent soundtrack. It's unlike anything I've ever played but the best analogy would be an xcom in real time.

And now for the bad: everything else. The micromanagement is endless and can get very frustrating because your agents will not do ANYTHING by themselves, including returning fire. You even have to select a new target every time you kill one, which also interupts any channeling skills you might be using on the respective agent immediately placing it on cooldown. I can't count the amount of times my agents run out of cover for no apparent reason during the round-robin click-fest of combat and or the amount of times they attempted to shoot through unbreakable walls/barriers instead of moving to a better firing position.

The levelling system seems completely useless. Everytime you level up or get a new piece of kit, all enemies magically get some kind of equivelant. Just got your first shield? Congratulations! Now every man and his ♥♥♥♥ing Patrol Dog too! Armour? We got that when you first hit level 5! Lasers weapons?! You must be new here...
They should have just removed the levelling/equipment aspect and just given you everything from the start because there is absolutely no reward for smashing your face into a wall long enough to level up enough or finding those prototypes deep in enemy territory. Atleast that way you're on the same level instead of playing catch up the whole way through.

The stealth system is the only option. However when you inevitably fail because of some random patrol or camera you're most likely going to die if you can't run away and hide from the endless amount of obscene enemy forces that spawn. So do what I did and destroy cameras (even though it will alert/ spawn guards) and shut down generators, and stealth kill as many patrols as you can so atleast your deaths aren't meaningless right? Wrong. Cameras respawn, generators turn back on, and patrols respawn incredibly quickly. I once hit the pause button to invest in a new skill only to find when I returned a patrol had respawned from thin air right in front of my face.

There's challenging and then there's padding combined with punishing you for overcoming that challenge. If you enjoy the latter, then get this game, but I can not recommend a game that I will probably never finish. For all those hours I only reached what I think is about halfway.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Commandos + Syndicate Wars = Satellite Reign

Its punishing, doesn't hold your hand or spoonfeed you. It can be frustrating and occasionally annoying. However, I love it.
Very open ended. A great sandbox to exercise your creativity. Excellent for those who love strong, emergent gameplay.

You basically control 4 agents - Infiltrator, Soldier, Hacker and Support - in a surprisingly large sandbox of a city. It's not a GTA like open world, but feels lived in and atmospheric.

You break into secure facilities and steal stuff. Method of approach is up to you. Plays a lot like Eidos's Commandos franchise, where you sneak around enemy bases.

The Agent's skills, the equipment and augmentations make all kinds of playstyles viable and fun. Hijack enemies and create a slave army, sneak in with suppressed weapons or blow up the main gate with Miniguns and grenades - its a very flexible game.

NOTE: AI quirks and inconsistencies can make the experience frustrating, especially for new players. It gets a lot better after the 8 hour mark. Play this if you have a lot of time at hand and like long game sesions.

reviewText: NOTE: THIS GAME IS GREATLY CPU INTENSIVE, MAKE SURE YOU HAVE A BEEFY CPU!\n\nThe review: After finally getting a cpu that can play this smoothly, this is a great game that was made by the developers of the original syndicate series, including syndicate and syndicate: wars. Do not let the syndicate from 2012 give you a tainted view on what was once a top notch game series, as these devs had nothing to do with it. Satellite reign is the spiritual successor to syndicate and syndicate wars, bringing new features and combining it with the old. If you have played the older syndicates then you most likely know what youre getting into, however if you havent then keep reading. you play the role of a CEO opperating a hostile takeover of this city after corperate corruption has overdone politics, you remotely control an elite team of 4 cloned operatives to do your bidding, research new tech and expand your secret corperate empire by taking control of the assets of your enemies. using your modified clones you will kill, steal, wreak havoc and coherse your way through an insanely detailed open world from a birds eye point of view. the controls are rather simple and the AI could have been improved a bit more but overall this game does the classics more justice than the shooter reboot in 2012. i do recommend getting it if youre a fan of the classic syndicate or if youre looking for a uniqe strategy/tactical experience.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. I loved Syndicate Wars. It is one of my favorite games on Playstation. Unfortunately, Satellite Reign is nowhere near as good. This game has potential, but it will not be reached until Satellite Reign II, if that ever comes out.

The thing I absolutely hated in Satellite Reign is mouse controls. The agents feel unresponsive sometimes, certain actions are very hard to get to activate at maximum camera height. It's also hard to get the agents to stand exactly where you need for the same reasons. Overall, the controls feel laggy and not precise enough.

This makes the game unplayable at times thanks to the fact that it is real-time. I was struggling to control my agents and get them to do exactly what I wanted them to in fights where more than two enemies were involved. Then there's the fact that the game doesn't save your location or certain game state elements. When you reload a saved game it simply places your agents at the neares respawn location. Basically, you can't try a certain approach and when it doesn't work just reload and try again. You'll have to run back from the damn spawn point, get all agents into positions, wait for the enemies to move into their positions... Basically, the game actively punishes you for reloading and tries to force you to live with the consequences of failed actions.

This could work for you, but it doesn't for me. I could ignore this if the rest of the game was tight, but it's just not.

Enemies keep respawning almost instantly if you take them out silently, makes clearing compounds stealthily to try and make a path for your Hacker completely pointless. It all boils down to two approaches: sneak past all the security cameras and guards or fight your way to the objective and back. If at least the missions had a bit more variety to them, but most of the missions in the first grid are just the same routine over and over again with nothing to do between them except for trying to get better clones.

Unless you're REALLY into Syndicate and want something to scratch that itch, go ahead and grab Satellite Reign. Otherwise, I don't recommend it.

reviewText:
Beyond the inevitable comparisons to Syndicate, this is a great game in its own right. It looks good (in high resolution) and plays very well considering that it's an indie game done on a kickstarter budget.

If you're like me and got into gaming during the 90s shareware era when there were lots of great games out that focused on innovative design, atomosphere and storytelling rather than recycling proven moneymaking formulas with slightly better graphics, you will probably love Satellite Reign.

I could critique some of the mechanics of it, but who cares? It's fun, aesthetically pleasing, well written and clearly a labor of love. If you love cyberpunk do not hesitate; this is your game.

reviewText:
Took a while for Satellite Reign to get it's hooks into me, but when it did... oh boy did it.  Always loved Syndicate, but Sydicate Wars was a dissapointment.  This is what I dreamed of.

I recommend enabling the pause/stim feature. Makes things much more enjoyable (the opinion of someone who loves turne-based).  I don't puse too much, but when things get sticky and you need to melee one unit while you hack into the mind of another and the other two clones take out the remainders. Silly fun, and I didn't realize you could hijack more than one unit, not till almost the end!!  Whoops.  I did encounter a few bugs, but no show stoppers. Didn't even use more than one manual save and the smart auto-saving process.

Again, there was some time invested before I could appreciate this game, and by that time the levels were getting more and more clever. Cutting the power to doors then hacking them to open them, put them in limbo.  But, cut the power back on and the door slip open.  Or stall them open by cutting the power right when a character walks through.

Reminder to self: This is a review, not a tip sheet.

In closing: This was $10 and time well spent. I have always been waiting Syndicate to end properly...  and now I feel like I can let go now.  5 Lives Studios, you did a great job developing on an already great idea.  If I spent $29.95, I would have been happy...  though I don't spend that kinda money on games anymore.  ;)

reviewText:
It's nice to see a modern-esque game inspired by the old Syndicate game. Some of the AI seems a bit dated, but it fits with the theme of the world. I'll exploit the AI to try to attack an objective multiple ways. It's still easy to get yourself killed if you don't get used to running early on, as you get more powerful then it's less of a concern. The world is setup so you can attempt an objective multiple ways, whether by stealth with one or more people, by force, by drones or hijaked people. There's several ways to get into areas as well, ziplines (you can attempt it even without gear and face falling off the line and right in front of guards), air vents, hacking, messing with hardware, hijaking guards who have keycards, to just blowing a hole through the main gate. Distractions can be beneficial. You have four character types: assault (explosions & bullet-sponge), support (group buffer & healer), hacker (hijaking & hacking), and infiltrator (assassination, stealing, & athletic feats).

A lot of features you don't realize are in the game unless you fumble into them, like double clicking character portraits to get from one person to the next when they're strewn across the map. The characters ability activation buttons are tiny, so it plays better if you just use the keyboard, especially since everything is realtime. Sometimes cover is wonky and aguard that should be able to see you when you're behind full cover runs up and starts bashing or trying to arrest you, and sounding the alarm. Sometimes while in scan mode guards will be mostly invisible, in a glitchy sorta way. Loading the game up has an attrotious load time, usually multiple minutes, luckily thats the only time it'll happen in the game.

I enjoy exploring the open world and hijaking the choice suspects and bribing scientists. I especially enjoy hijaking drones and guards/police and making them run amok through the town or on missions, it's a frequent distraction method I use. I like going the slow plodding way in missions, taking what I want and assassinating guards to make my route clear for exfil. I like the graphics and am surpirsed that they used that level of graphics for the tiniest things. This game has room for improvement, but it's been a bit of a guilty pleasure game for me.

If you enjoy the cyberpunk theme, syndicate, multiple ways to accomplish goals, or RPG's you might just like this game. Watch an LP if you're on the fence.

reviewText:
Quick summary: highly recommended.
I wanted to see something like this in a long time. One of my first reviews on steam, so will just to in regular fasion.

Pros:
Amazing atmosphere, good gameplay.

What was the last game in recent N years that made you think while not being a puzzle? This can be the one. You have one of two major opportunities for any mission: bash or stealth. Though even forcing will not work for you if you go headon without using some brain. Seen some other review where people were wincing for force like never works, that is completely wrong. Force can get you through with this game, but not singlehandedly.

Heroes: nice look, some RPG system.

Stealth: Locations in game have lots of stealth attributes like Cameras/CentryTowers/Gates, but all of these can be negated by hacking/rewiring power generators or security terminals and backdoors of course.

Bruteforce: Health/Armr/Shield/Guns as usual. Bonus with environmental terrain. Enemies calling for support. And nice feature of making own army by taking enemies under control.

Video: Setting is nice hyberpunk style. I can't say it is super-duper scenery, but it is pleasant all around and it has it's nice scenery and vista points to get to. I'd prefer it being a bit less resource intensive and it being more smooth though.

Audio: Nice background fitting the setting with variations for fight/stealth/etc.

General: Has feeling of old-school games, ie Cyndicate and also Neromancer book.


Cons:
Stealth is pretty much not worth it atm, as brute forcing most of the game is easier and gives more income/benefits.

Some lack of chars management, like seldom auto-path glitches or no auto-fire feature.

Overall:
Highly recommended. I don't buy much stuff, but this thing is worth it. If you see discount -- higly recommended to aqcuire.

reviewText:
I've been a massive fan of Syndicate and Syndicate Wars since their releases. They've consistently been some of my favorite games and I've always remembered them very fondly. Here's what's different this time:

Corporations are monolithic institutions with control over every facet of the world. The police are omnipresent, but if you get caught by them, they're just as likely to beat you and rob you as they are to arrest you. Everything you see is connected to a network which can be exploited to breach all sorts of security. Civilians are everywhere, but they don't really do anything other than walk around aimlessly and have no real purpose.

Oh...oh THE GAME! The game, right. Satellite Reign is awesome and it's an excellent Syndicate game. If you liked Syndicate you should check it out. If you loved the Syndicate games, you need to buy this one.

reviewText:
My previous review was positive.

Having played the game past the tutorial, I'd say think twice before buying this. It's finicky, repetitive (even very early on) and you'll be repeating missions until everything lines up correctly (i.e. by chance) There's very few ways to do missions and the loading times are very long.

So enjoy that. The controls are also poor, as is pathfinding. My agents have been stuck inside buildings and walls several times which leads to reloading again. And don't forget - you can't save inside a mission, so you're right back at the start. How ♥♥♥♥ing wonderful is that? I bet you want to punch the idiot developer that made that decision right? I sure do.

♥♥♥♥♥ on the corpse of the old syndicate, but slightly less so that the other remakes.

It's also very buggy. Agents get stuck inside buildings, disobey your orders and if left alone, will just comply with arrest orders (even if you've told them to run away beforehand, you'll have to do so again). This in a game without pausing and being able to give orders.

So yeah, do you want to deal with all that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t?

reviewText: Satellite Reign is a very good proof of concept that truly captures the mood and feel of the classic Syndicate games. What isn't asked though, is if that is a very good idea. I remember the Syndicate games feeling old only a few years after their release. The combat controls just weren't precise enough and the environments and missions felt samey.\n\nReign's story, limited though it is, makes more sense than Syndicates, one long night of bringing down a corporation. It too suffers from average controls, lacking in finese to get your agents to do what you want. In stealth and hacking, the game succeeds. That is why I recommend this game. It's satisfying and very well made, but the game they were emulating perhaps wasn't the best idea. It is very good that a carbon copy was not made.

reviewText:
Novahot
This game really surpassed my expectations. Not only is it a worthy successor to the Syndicate games, it significantly improves and expands on the formula of the originals.

Satellite Reign introduces expansive stealth mechnanics and infiltration in addition to the tactical combat of the Syndicate titles. You can ghost the missions, go in guns blazing or combine both approaches to great effect.

5Lives also really nailed the dystopian setting and Neon-Cyperpunk aesthetic. You can tell this game was made by fans of the genre.

A+

reviewText:
This game is sitting right between a thumbs-up and a thumbs-down for me.  The game is solid and it has a good artstyle that nails the cyberpunk genre.  I love the open city gameplay, along with all of the things to do: rob banks, siphon money off ATMs, steal data, break people out of jail, etc.

The main problem for me is the lack of fun.  That's just my personal tastes, nothing against this game or how it was made.  I prefer a slower paced, almost turn-based approach.  I would LOVE to have a pause option in order to fully control the 4 agents better.

Small nitpick.  The pathfinding isn't the greatest.  Several times I had to scroll around the map trying to find an agent who was stuck infinitely running into a wall.

reviewText:
I doubt there are too many reviews of SR out there that dont, at some point, reference the classic game The Syndicate, so there, I'm getting it out of the way early. A lot of the play is along those lines, except in a persistent, semi-open world environment. And that's a good thing! It takes that old atmosphere and modernizes it very well, while adding in a somewhat more freeform gameplay style. The ability to affect the environment (cameras, doors, etc) definitely adds a lot of interesting possibilities to a given run.

So if pointy-clicky strategy games or strong cyberpunk environments are your jam, I recommend it.

That's not to say it's perfect. I'd definitely have to say that it gets repetetive after a while. I also wish the story was much more fleshed out. There's a lot of potential for storytelling here, but even with the included novella it seems somewhat thin. And as a consequence of that, now and then I found myself getting into that mentality of wait
date: why am I doing this mission again? Does this one matter or is it just for resources?"\n\nStill
recommended: I definitely enjoy it. And although I didn't get it on it back when it was a Kickstarter
hoursPlayed: I'd hold it up as a success for crowdfunding in general."

reviewText:
are you a Commandos fan?
well buy this game! cause its your futuristic cyberpunk Commandos-like game.
are you a XCOM fan?
well buy this game too, cause its your real-time strategy XCOM!

now lets rant about the awesomeness of this title:
AGENTS: Satellite reign is a real time tactical squad strategy game, god that was mouthful...anyway you control four agents each with certain set of skills (Class Based as mentioned in its description) so you have a soldier as your frontliner and damage soaker/dealer, you have a support/medic that can heal and operate as a team leader and buff your other agents, a hacker that can hack atms and security doors/cameras and also HIJACK people how awesome is that!, and of course lastly my favorate class the assassin that can snipe people from a far or slice them up and close in stealth, your agents level up and you spend their points the way you want your agents to perform you can also customize your agents with augmentations from techs you steal and research, buy awesome laser and plasma prototype weapons and also a variety of gears each with a certain purpose to it.
MAP: now lets talk about the map, the game has a HUGE map different districts to get access to and a lot of corporations that you need to infiltrate and encounter in order to progress and aquire techs, you can travel through the map by walking and that take time cause its really huge, or you can respawn your agents using becons scattered around in every district.
Objectives: the game offers a variety of objectives and different WELL THOUGHT AND IMPLEMENTED ways to achive those objectives, through bribes, recruiting informants, hijacking indeviduals and sometimes getting your hands dirty and bloody to get informations.
Satellite reign is a 10/10 game for me, the game offers everything a tactical squad game player can hope for, the only downside for me is there is no voiceover for the characters and since I am a creature driver by sounds I find that side lacking, everything else is perfect.

thanks for reading

reviewText:
EDIT: Due to the game developers doing a good job in fixing bugs after release, I have now changed my original negative review into a positive one. For reference, here is my original negative review:

Great game, however it was released out of Early Access a bit too early. There are still a few bugs that must be fixed. Therefore, I cannot recommend the game at this time.

I am unable to complete a mission due to a character, whom I was supposed to escort, getting wounded during a mission and not respawning. Therefore, I am currently waiting for this bug to be fixed before I continue my game.

I am not the only one having this issue. Several other people have reported similar problems on the Steam forums.

Also, it happens quite often that characters get stuck.

Once these bugs (and a few other issues) have been fixed, I will gladly change my negative rating for this game into a positive one.

reviewText:
I love this game.  I played Syndicate (1993) to death, and this is the best successor that I have yet seen.

I guess it took some time after the kickstarter to get some of the bugs ironed out and the performance dialed in -- but I missed out on that.  By the time I started playing, it ran smooth and I didn't encounter any problems in my first 40 hour playthrough (maybe some of that was idling time).

I found it to be smooth and polished.  I enjoyed the cyber-noire story and it was worth finding all the terminals to make sure that all of the narative was revealed (I did use some maps I found online for this, as well as the Steam achievemnents list so that I would know when I found all the terminals in a given zone).

There are lots of valid aproaches to playing.  You can go loud and shoot everything up, or use brain-jacked agents to open all the doors as you speed-run through, or take your time and stealth everything.  You can even stealth the final boss fight if you have the patience for it.

Now that the coop beta is out, I expect to give this a lot of replay.  I have a few friends in different time zones that I think will play, and each group can keep its own persistant multiplayer save.

I usually review games with a list of caviats and qualifications, but in this case I have none. I have no detractors to caution you about, and endorse this wholeheartedly.

Do check through the forums though, as it seems some folks have some complaints.
